metadata.case_name: Lakshmanan Chettiar & Ors. v. State of Madras

facts.text: On November 18, 1953, the Prohibition Officer, Madras City, and the Deputy Commissioner of Police made a search of premises No. 28, Thanikachala Chetty Street, Thyagarayanagar, Madras, and seized several bottles of foreign liquor and glasses containing whisky and soda.
The appellant, Lakshmanan Chettiar, was residing at the premises.
The other three appellants, A. S. Krishna, R. Venkataraman and V. S. Krishnaswamy, were found drinking from the glass tumblers.
All the four were immediately put under arrest and in due course charge-sheets were laid against them for offences under the Act.
The three appellants other than Lakshmanan Chettiar were charged under ss. 4(1)(a) and 4(1)(j) for possession and consumption of liquor.

Lakshmanan Chettiar was charged under s. 4(1)(k) for allowing the above acts in premises in his immediate possession, under s. 12 for abetment of the offences, and under s. 4(1)(a) on the allegation that though he was a permit-holder, he was in possession of more units than were allowed under the permit.

Immediately after service of summons, the appellants filed an application under s. 432 of the Criminal Procedure Code, contending that ss. 4(2) and 28 to 32 of the Act were repugnant to the provisions of the Constitution, and prayed that the above question might be referred for the decision of the High Court.
The Third Presidency Magistrate allowed the application and referred to the High Court as many as seven questions on the constitutionality of various sections of the Act.
This reference was heard by Rajamannar, C.J., and Umamaheswaram, J., who held that ss. 4(2) and 28 to 32 were valid, and answered the reference against them, judgment dated May 7, 1954.
Against this judgment, the appellants have preferred the present appeals under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss. 4(2), 28, 29, 30, 31 and 32 of the Madras Prohibition Act No. X of 1937 are unconstitutional and void.

Whether the impugned provisions are repugnant to s. 107 of the Government of India Act, 1935, because they are repugnant to the provisions of existing Indian laws with respect to the same matter, to wit, Indian Evidence Act I of 1872 and Criminal Procedure Code Act No. V of 1898.
Whether the impugned sections are repugnant to Art. 14 of the Constitution, and have therefore become void under Art. 13(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 4(2) and ss. 28 to 32 of the Act are void under s. 107 of the Government of India Act, 1935, because they are repugnant to the provisions of existing Indian laws (Indian Evidence Act and Criminal Procedure Code).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 107 Government of India Act, 1935; Entries 5 and 2 Concurrent List (Criminal Procedure, Evidence)

petitioner_arguments.text: Though the Act is within the competence of the Provincial Legislature in so far as it prohibits possession, sale, consumption, etc., of liquor under s. 4(1), the matters dealt with under s. 4(2) and ss. 28 to 32 fall within Entries 5 and 2 respectively of List III (Concurrent List), and to that extent, the legislation is on matters enumerated in the Concurrent List.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Provincial List Entry 31; Concurrent List Entries 2,5

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 4(2) enacting a presumption to be drawn by the court on certain facts being established, deals with what is purely a matter of evidence; ss. 28 to 32 deal with matters pertaining to Criminal Procedure, such as warrants, seizure and arrest.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Evidence Act; Criminal Procedure Code

petitioner_arguments.text: The presumptions raised in s. 4(2) of the Act are repugnant to Art. 14 of the Constitution; the facts set out in s. 4(2) on which the presumption of guilt is raised have no reasonable relation to the offences themselves.

court_reasoning.text: The Madras Prohibition Act, as a whole, is a law in respect of intoxicating liquors, falling within Entry 31 of the Provincial list. The presumptions in s. 4(2) are to be raised only in the trial of offences under s. 4(1) of the Act and are purely ancillary to the exercise of the legislative power in respect of Entry 31 in List II. Similarly, provisions in ss. 28 to 32 are only with reference to offences committed or suspected under the Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pith and substance of the legislation is intoxicating liquors (Provincial List Entry 31); ancillary provisions do not make it fall under Concurrent List.

court_reasoning.text: For s. 107(1) GOI Act to apply, provisions must be in respect of a matter in Concurrent List and repugnant; here, entire Act falls outside s. 107 as Provincial subject.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine of pith and substance: legislation valid if in substance on Provincial matter, even if incidentally trenches on Concurrent matters.

court_reasoning.text: s. 4(2) does not offend Art. 14; presumptions have rational connection to offences when read distributively (possession of liquor presumes offence under 4(1)(a), etc.); upheld even under due process standards in US cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumptions are rebuttable and rationally connected; no denial of equal protection.

holdings.text: The Madras Prohibition Act is in its entirety a law within the exclusive competence of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 31 List II, and the question of repugnancy under s. 107(1) does not arise.
s. 4(2) does not violate Art. 14; presumptions are reasonable and ancillary to the main legislation.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, holding that ss. 4(2) and 28 to 32 of the Madras Prohibition Act, 1937 are intra vires and not repugnant to s.107 GOI Act 1935 or Art.14 Constitution, applying pith and substance doctrine.

key_quotes.text: The point for decision in these appeals is whether ss. 4(2), 28, 29, 30, 31 and 32 of the Madras Prohibition Act No. X of 1937... are unconstitutional and void.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: if a statute is found in substance to relate to a topic within the competence of the legislature, it should be held to be intra vires, even though it might incidentally trench on topics not within its legislative competence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key application of pith and substance doctrine.

key_quotes.text: The Madras Prohibition Act is thus in its entirety a law within the exclusive competence of the Provincial Legislature, and the question of repugnancy under s. 107(1) does not arise.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We are unable to see how s. 4(2) offends the requirement as to equality before law or the equal protection of laws.
key_quotes.speaker: court
